content.description: This is the obvious offwidth on the south side of Worm Drive proper.  It goes up a slot for about ten feet then over a three or four foot roof, going to easier vertical terrain after that.  The name gives some hint to the beta.  This is a must do classic for anyone seeking out Vedauwoos hard offwidths.
content.protection: Three #5 Friends should do nicely.  Bolts up top.
content.location: This is on the south side of Worm Drive, to the left of the big obvious chimney.  There is a good 5.9 warmup two cracks to the right of it with bolts on top.

content.description:
This is a spectacular and tall boulder problem.  It starts out as very overhanging tight hands and quickly narrows to thin fingers as it rounds out a bulge, then it opens up to flared and then bomber but dirty hands as the bulge rounds over, stranding you on a shelf about twenty feet up.  Then you have to climb up some more easy but vertical terrain for about fifteen feet, popping through a hole up top to end up on top of the formation.  The last fifteen feet is strewn with good handjams and is pretty secure.  Watch out for the moss in the crack at the top of the bulge, you may want to bring out a brush on a long stick or rap down and brush this section, as the moss is thick enough to make it insecure, and you wouldn't want to fall from here.

This thing doesn't get done much, if ever.  In fact, it has probably only ever been done once.
content.protection: One pad is actually sufficient.  Lay it on the ground at the base of the climb, and have a spotter stand on the big obvious rock.  If you fall off the crux (before you completely round the bulge) have your spotter give you a light push onto the pad.  After you reach the first good hands, don't fall.  To get off, walk off the back(south) side of the formation.
content.location: This is below the south side of Worm Drive Rocks, see the pictures.

content.description:
I'm sure this route has been done before (the official route name and FA info would be appreciated). It's a pretty fun little jaunt and not a bad warm-up if "

Driving Miss Wormy

" is occupied. Begin in a narrow, rectangular alcove to the left of the bolted slab climb

Return to Sender

. Climb up under the roof crack on the right side of the alcove, plug a fist-size piece at the lip then pull around said roof on good fist jams and well-defined edges for your feet. Finish by climbing the low-angled fist crack in a right-facing dihedral, and go to the anchor bolts of

Return to Sender

.
content.protection:
A single rack plus 1 BD C4 #4. An extra fist size piece (BD #3) is nice if you aren't confident at the grade. This shares a bolted anchor with

Return to Sender

.
content.location:
To climber's left of the bolted slab climb

Return to Sender

is a small, boxy alcove. Begin here.

content.description: Climb the awkward, right-leaning offwidth for approximately 20 feet. Enter a squeeze chimney pod. The crack will taper to hand/fist size. Climb through a small bulge, and then continue on easier ground for another 15 feet. A set of rappel anchors are located 15 feet to the climber's right.
content.protection: Large cams for the bottom (I used a Valley Giant, but a #6 is sufficient). Bring medium-size cams for the top.
content.location: This ascends the prominent, long offwidth on the south-facing side of the Mechanical Transmission Craig.

content.description: This crack is nestled in a right-facing dihedral and begins with an offwidth pod which gradually closes down to tips. The crack then begins yawning slowly from tight hands to deep fists while the angle of the climb increases and the feet disappear. The crack closes back down once more to good hands for a few feet before opening back up to fists/off fists as the feet reappear and the angle decreases.
content.protection: Pro from #0.75-#5, two rap hangers at the top.
content.location:
This burly beauty can be found 50 yards to the right of

Worm Drive

just past the bolted slabs/chimney in a right-facing dihedral.

content.description: Climb a right-slanting, sloper rail to a fun, sloper top-out.
content.protection: Crash pad, spotter.
content.location: Beginning at Acres parking area, walk down the trail towards The Citadel.  The fence on the right will go away, and when it comes back head up the rock slope on your right.  This boulder is to the left, and can be recognized by a large tree behind it.

content.description:
A short distance to the right of

Worm Drive

is this well-bolted arete.  Follow the obvious line of bolts to the anchors at the top.  This route is excellent and should not be missed.  If you take the time to walk all the way out to the Worm Drive area, make sure this route is on your tick list.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors.
content.location:
This is in the same general area as

Worm Drive

itself, to the right of same in small alcove.

content.protection: 6 bolts to an anchor with chains.
content.location:
Return to Sender follows the left side of the slab just right of "

Von's Chicken Coop

."  Bob Scarpelli soloed

Von's

to put an anchor for "

Love Letters

"on the right side of the slab. "

Love Letters

" is incorrectly identified as "

Sent For You Yesterday

" which is around the corner to climber's right on a arete. Both of these routes (

Love Letters

and

Sent for You Yesterday

) were put up by Bob Scarpelli and friends.

content.description:
Pigeon Nest Crack has awkward, insecure, chimney pod moves with debris to an easy right-angling hand and fist ramp. Belay on gear at the top.

It’s there, and someone had to do it.
content.protection:
One 9” Valley Giant, 1 to 2 each: #1 to #5 (old size) Camalots.

Gear for belay anchor: #0.4 to #1 Camalots which you can leave at the top before rapping down.
content.location: It is in the Interior Chasm on the NE face.

content.description: Philly Cheesesteak is a nice, thin crack with a crux up high. It is taller than it looks in the photo.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location: Walk past The Acres toward The Citadel. The trail begins to parallel a fence and takes you through a small aspen grove. About 200 feet after those aspens, turn left, and pick up a faint trail the will take you past another stand of aspens on your right. Philly Cheesesteak can be found in the boulders there in a hallway. Approximate GPS coordinates are: 41°09'23.7"N 105°20'05.1"W.

content.description: This climb is found between two huge blocks to the left of Sent for You Yesterday.  It is an overhanging chimney that starts out as a stemming size and never gets small enough to use a #6 Camalot.  The chimney stops with a block on top that contains a difficult, flared, hand jam (crux) to the anchors.
content.protection: Anchors are not so great - use carefully.
content.location:
It is at the East end of Worm Drive crag left of

Sent for You Yesterday

.

content.description: This is an amazing squeeze chimney. Wiggle and squeeze your way to the top, and walk off. There are plenty of palm presses and leg locks. This is a true offwidth boulder problem.
content.protection: Walk off.
content.location:
The start is to the left of the trail headed to

Worm Drive

proper. Head through the boulders where the trail veers right, and it’s located under

Worm Drive

.

content.description: This is a offwidth roof to a topout through jaws.  Start on the two deepest fist jams.  It is one of the easier offwidth roofs in Vedauwoo, and it is good practice pulling lips on some of the harder offwidths out there.
content.protection: Pad, spotter.
content.location:
This route is located in the valley behind

Spider Killer

.  It is on a small formation between

Spider Killer

and

Eight Ounces to Freedom

.

From

Spider Killer

:  Walk through the boulders to the on the backside of

Spider Killer

.  You will dip down in a valley with a cow trail going down the center of it.  A very large boulder will appear on the right, there is a caven underneath.  This is the backside of Jaws.  Continue around the boulder and go through a corridor to get to Jaws.

content.description:
This route goes from fingers to hands to fists to offwidth. Start from the wind sheltered alcove to the right of

Driving Miss Wormy

and finger lock, hand jam, and chickenwing your way to the two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Finger size through #5 Camalot, which protects the OW at the top.
content.location:
This route is just right of

Driving Miss Wormy

.

content.description:
One of Vedauwoos hardest offwidth ticks, this is a burly bastard.

Start under the roof on hands and follow these into deepening fists, thugging your way over the wide lip and into substantially easier terrain to the top.
content.protection: A couple of pads will do. It's nice to have a spotter, as your inside foot can get quite stuck while turning the lip, and they can help you pull it out.
content.location:
It is right across (north) the aspen grove from

Where The Wild Things Are

and a little to the east.

content.description:
This is a perfect beginner's hand crack just to the right of worm drive.  This crack is left leaning and utilizes the left side as a slab/ramp for feet. Begin behind the large boulder. A 'crux' move is near the top when the crack opens up to a fist jam.  The climb finishes out left to a 5.4 slab.  Belay from the worm drive anchors or behind the top of the slab- then lower off

Worm Drive

's anchors.
content.protection:
Hand sizes & a #4 Camalot (protects the top before the slab).  Lower off of

Worm Drive

's anchors.
content.location:
This climb is just right of

Worm Drive

about 7 feet.

content.description: This ascends a left-facing corner leaning to the left. It is mostly hands and fists with a wide pod near the top. Climb this fun crack that is mostly steep climbing on solid jams. Belay from bolts well back from the top.
content.protection: #0.5 to #5 (old size) Camalots with an emphasis on #2 to #3 sizes and an optional 9” Valley Giant.
content.location: It is in the Interior Chasm on the South corner.

content.description: Dark Energy ascends a right-facing corner leaning to the right, sized between an OW and a squeeze. This is a fun endeavor! Try to avoid stemming at the start. Belay from a bolt anchor on top. The rating includes the endurance factor.
content.protection: #3 to #5 (old size) Camalots with an emphasis on the large sizes. Also, bring a 9” Valley Giant or equivalent.
content.location: It is in the Interior Chasm on the West corner.

content.description:
This is a chimney with three routes on the inside of the Manual Transmission Crag. It’s not a true climb itself but warrants its own description. I’ve approached it from the back (north) side onto the platform, then climbed up the easy wide slot (

Unkn 3

) and rappelled into the chasm from a natural gear anchor. Leaving a fixed line is prudent just in case.

It may be possible to squeeze and chimney in from the south side but with complications and unpleasantries.

From the top of the chasm, you can get off by rapping from anchors either to the N or the S.
content.protection: Anchor for rappel is #0.4 to # 1 Camalots.
content.location: It is inside Mechanical Transmission Crag.

content.description: Climb a left-arching, hand & fist to OW/chimney slot. It is a bit different, although maybe not for Vedauwoo. At the top, rig an anchor with gear and/or use your body. Doesn’t that description make it a “must-do”? To get off, scramble down through a maze of slots and ramps to the North, or rap from anchor on top of the OW to East, 5.7/5.8.
content.protection: Pro is recommended. Rack from #1 to # 4 Camalots with an optional bigger piece at the start.
content.location: This is on the left (East) end of the back side.

content.description: Climb an easy, offwidth slot in corner. Scramble up easy terrain, and negotiate through a tighter section up higher.
content.protection: Optional 1 or 2 wide pieces.
content.location: This is on the left/center of the back side.

content.description: This is a medium-length, left-angling, tight hand & fist semi-splitter. It is a nice, fun climb that’s awkward in spots which is part of the fun. Belay on gear at the top, 5.8/5.9.
content.protection: One VG or=, then rack from #0.75 to #3.5 Camalots. Bring gear for a belay anchor from #0.4 to #1 Camalots.
content.location: This is in the center on the back side.

content.description: Climb a short, vertical, wide section then a short, left-angling, hand and fist semi-splitter. Belay from bolts on the top. The anchor has chains to rap (60’ to ledge or 75’ to the bottom of the cleft).
content.protection: A rack of medium to large cams.
content.location: This is on the back side - on the right (West) end.
